Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: 41. A landlord’s failure to maintain essential services, such as heat, in accordance with applicable law and code requirements can constitute a direct or indirect interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, giving rise to liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 broadly to cover a landlord’s reckless failure to maintain sanitary conditions that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, but the facts and analysis concern repeated sewage flooding and porous walls, not the failure to provide heat or other essential services as such. The court’s explicit discussion of § 14 focuses on interference with quiet enjoyment and not on the separate statutory clause governing willful failure to furnish utilities or essential services like heat. Thus, while Simon is strong authority that serious code-violating conditions interfering with habitability can violate quiet enjoyment under § 14, it does not specifically establish the proposition about failure to maintain essential services such as heat.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The objectives of these statutes go beyond deterrence of intentional wrongdoing; unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case discusses liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for a landlord’s failure to take measures against criminal/drug activity in common areas, but it does not involve essential services like heat or building systems, nor does it tie liability to violation of code requirements for such services. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition that failure to maintain essential services such as heat in accordance with codes constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant has failed to take any measures… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

A violation of these health and safety regulations may constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly relies on the State Sanitary Code as defining the landlord’s non-waivable duty to supply adequate heat and hot water, specifically citing the then-current and current regulatory provisions (including 105 C.M.R. 410.200 and 410.201). It further characterizes a substantial Sanitary Code violation as rendering a dwelling uninhabitable and grounds rent abatement for breach of the warranty of habitability, which in Massachusetts is closely linked to interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus the case supports the proposition that these Code-based heating requirements are enforceable landlord obligations whose violation can constitute a serious breach of tenant rights.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable. … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable.”

Garwacki establishes a general negligence duty: landlords, like others, must exercise reasonable care to avoid subjecting others to unreasonable risk of harm, including on demised premises. It does not address heating systems, lawful temperature requirements, or characterize the landlord’s duty as “non‑delegable” with respect to building systems or code compliance. Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … Our statutes do not support limiting a landlord’s negligence liability to areas under his control.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: 45. Defendant’s failure to provide heat in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, after receiving notice and having a reasonable opportunity to cure, constitutes at least a negligent and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable where conduct or omissions, even if not intentional, foreseeably result in substantial interference); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The proposition uses Blackett not for its specific facts (noise from a lounge) but for the governing principle that a landlord’s conduct or omissions can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment even without an intent to deprive, so long as the substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do. Blackett expressly rejects a strict intent requirement and emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling, citing prior cases including failure to supply heat. That reasoning directly supports using Blackett as authority for treating a code-based failure to provide heat, after notice and opportunity to cure, as at least negligent and unreasonable interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services)... Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.

Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute, which imposes strict liability, automatically constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court holds that at least negligent conduct (notice or reason to know plus failure to take appropriate corrective measures) is required, and nowhere discusses the adequacy of attempted repairs or a situation where the landlord makes some repairs but the harmful condition continues. Thus, it does not address or support the specific proposition about liability despite partial repair efforts.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: Wideman involves severe habitability problems (lack of heat, infestations, and other serious defects) and mentions that the trial judge also found a breach of quiet enjoyment, but the SJC expressly notes that no damages were awarded on that theory to avoid duplication and does not analyze what constitutes a ‘substantial’ interference with quiet enjoyment. The opinion is focused on the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy, not on defining or applying the ‘substantial interference’ standard under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition that conditions like sustained code‑deficient temperatures, extra heat costs, illness, and loss of normal use amount to ‘substantial’ interference with quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
